In other words, if we had placed a straight edge to be tangential in all positions to the primitive curve, the turning must have been reached, after which the rotation would be in the reverse direction. A point on the curve at which the gradient ceases to rise and begins to fall is called a point of contamination, while the turning in the opposite direction is called a point of inflection.

We may regard this question from either the graphic aspect or the physical. The graphical aspect makes it necessary to determine the changes of inclination, and therefore to find values of x for the bending moment.

The physical considerations deal with the value of the bending moment as the beam arrives at the same result, which is expressed by the following argument: the bending moment, which is expressed by \text{M} \text{ changes sign,} and is indicated by the curve of the beam (see Fig. 23), and thereafter at two points the bending moment must be zero, since the variation in it is uniform.
